The morning mist clung to the Highland loch like a shroud, obscuring the jagged peaks that pierced the grey sky beyond. Sergeant Moira Gash pulled her oars through the dark water with practiced strokes, her breath forming small clouds in the crisp air. This was her sanctuary, these pre-dawn hours when Inverness still slumbered and the world belonged only to her and the ancient waters that had shaped her since childhood.

She had been rowing these lochs for thirty-seven years, first as a gangly child desperate to escape the cramped tenement where her mother's coughing fits echoed through paper-thin walls, then as a teenager seeking solace from the relentless teasing about her unusual height and angular features. Now, at forty-two, with silver threading through her auburn hair and lines etched around her green eyes from years of squinting into Scottish weather, rowing remained her constant companion. The rhythmic pull of the oars, the burn in her shoulders, the way the boat glided forward with each stroke – these sensations grounded her in ways that her work as a police sergeant rarely could.

The radio crackled to life on the seat beside her, shattering the morning's peace. "Control to Sergeant Gash. Priority call. Missing person report just came in. Teenage girl, last seen three days ago in Drumnadrochit."

Moira shipped her oars and reached for the radio, water dripping from her gloved fingers onto the plastic casing. "Gash here. Details?"

"Sixteen-year-old Emma MacLeod. Parents say she was walking to meet friends at the village hall but never arrived. Her mobile's going straight to voicemail. Family's beside themselves."

Another missing teenager. That made four in the past eight months across the Highlands – all between fifteen and eighteen, all seemingly vanishing without a trace. The official line was that young people sometimes ran away, seeking adventure in Glasgow or Edinburgh, but something in Moira's gut suggested otherwise. In her twenty years of police work, she had developed an instinct for patterns that others missed, connections that existed in shadows and silences rather than in official reports.

"I'll be there in forty minutes," she said into the radio. "Have someone canvas the route from her house to the village hall again. And get me everything we have on the other missing kids from the past year."

"Already on it, Sarge. Though the brass won't like you connecting cases without evidence."

Moira allowed herself a bitter smile. Chief Inspector Hartwell had made his feelings clear about her "tendency toward conspiracy theories" during their last heated exchange. He was a numbers man, focused on clearance rates and budget constraints, not on the subtle wrongness that seemed to permeate these disappearances. But Moira had learned to trust her instincts, even when they led her into conflict with superiors who preferred neat explanations to messy truths.

She started the small outboard motor and turned toward shore, the peaceful morning now shadowed by thoughts of another family's nightmare. The boat cut through the mist-shrouded water as she mentally reviewed what she knew about the missing teenagers. They came from different towns scattered across the Highlands, with no apparent connection to each other. Different schools, different social circles, different backgrounds. Yet something linked them, something that existed beyond the reach of conventional investigation.

As she approached the boat launch, Moira noticed an unfamiliar figure standing on the small wooden dock. A woman, perhaps in her fifties, wearing a paint-stained smock over dark clothing. Her grey hair was pulled back severely, and her pale blue eyes seemed to track Moira's approach with unusual intensity. Most people avoided the launch this early in the morning, preferring the warmth of their beds to the Highland chill.

"Beautiful morning for rowing," the woman called out as Moira guided her boat alongside the dock. Her voice carried a slight accent that Moira couldn't immediately place – perhaps Welsh, or from somewhere in the south of England.

"Aye, it is that," Moira replied, securing her boat and beginning to lift it from the water. Despite her lean build, years of rowing had given her considerable upper body strength, and she could manage the lightweight craft on her own.

"I'm Peggy," the woman said, stepping closer. "Peggy Thorne. I've just moved to the area – bought the old cottage up on Ben Wyvis. Thought I might try my hand at some landscape painting while the light is still soft."

Moira paused in securing her boat. Something about the woman's manner struck her as off – too casual, too carefully rehearsed. And there was something else, a quality to her pale eyes that made Moira's policeman instincts prickle with unease.

"Remote spot for painting," Moira observed. "Not many neighbors up that way."

"Oh, I prefer solitude for my work," Peggy said with a smile that didn't quite reach her eyes. "I do portraits, mostly. Young people have such interesting faces, don't you think? So full of possibility and hope. I find them endlessly fascinating subjects."

The radio crackled again, reminding Moira of the missing girl and her waiting duties. She lifted her equipment bag and nodded politely to the strange woman. "Well, I hope you find what you're looking for up here."

"I'm quite certain I will," Peggy replied, her pale eyes following Moira as she walked toward her car.

Driving toward Drumnadrochit, Moira found herself thinking about the encounter. There had been something deeply unsettling about Peggy Thorne, though she couldn't articulate exactly what. Perhaps it was the woman's intense focus on young faces, or the way she had seemed to be waiting specifically for someone to arrive at the boat launch. Or maybe it was simply the accumulation of too many missing teenagers and not enough answers, making her see shadows where none existed.

The MacLeod house sat on a hill overlooking Loch Ness, its windows facing the dark water that had made their village famous. Moira had visited many grieving families over the years, but she never became accustomed to the particular anguish of parents whose children had simply vanished. At least with other tragedies – accidents, illnesses, even violent crimes – there was usually a body, a explanation, some form of closure. Missing persons cases left families suspended in a horrible limbo, hoping and dreading in equal measure.

Janet MacLeod met her at the door, her eyes red-rimmed and desperate. "Any news?" she asked before Moira had even crossed the threshold.

"Not yet, but we're exploring every possibility," Moira said gently. "I know this is difficult, but I need to ask you some more questions about Emma's routine, her friends, anyone new who might have come into her life recently."

They sat in a living room dominated by photographs of Emma – school portraits, family holidays, candid shots that captured a vibrant girl with dark hair and bright eyes. Moira had studied these images in the initial report, but seeing them displayed in the family's context made Emma's absence feel more acute.

"She's never done anything like this before," Janet said for perhaps the dozenth time since her daughter's disappearance. "Emma tells us everything. If she was planning to go somewhere, she would have said something."David MacLeod sat heavily in his armchair, his weathered hands clasped tightly together. He was a man who worked with his hands, Moira could tell from the permanently stained fingernails and the callused palms. A fisherman, most likely, or perhaps someone who worked the tourist boats that plied Loch Ness during the warmer months. His voice, when he finally spoke, carried the weight of three sleepless nights and the growing fear that his daughter might never come home.

"She was excited about something that day," he said slowly, his Highland accent thick with emotion. "More excited than usual. Kept checking her phone and smiling to herself. When Janet asked her about it, she just said she'd made a new friend who understood her art. Emma's been drawing since she could hold a pencil, you see. Always sketching the loch, the hills, the old ruins. Said she wanted to be an artist someday, maybe study in Edinburgh or Glasgow."

Moira made notes, though something cold settled in her stomach at the mention of art and a new friend. The coincidence felt too sharp, too pointed to ignore. "Did she mention this friend's name? Where they met?"

Janet shook her head, dabbing at her eyes with a tissue that had been twisted into a rope from constant use. "She was secretive about it, which wasn't like Emma at all. Said she'd met someone who could help her with her technique, someone who really understood what she was trying to achieve with her drawings. We thought maybe it was a new teacher at school, or perhaps someone from one of those art groups that meet in Inverness."

"I'll need to speak with Emma's friends," Moira said, closing her notebook. "Sometimes teenagers confide in their peers about things they won't tell their parents. And I'd like to see her room, if that's all right. Sometimes we can learn things from what someone leaves behind."

Emma's bedroom was a testament to her artistic ambitions. Sketches covered nearly every surface – careful studies of Highland landscapes, portraits of friends and family, and what appeared to be preliminary work for larger compositions. The drawings showed genuine talent, Moira thought, the kind of skill that would indeed attract the attention of someone interested in nurturing young artists. Or someone who used that interest as a means to gain trust and access.

The girl's laptop sat open on her desk, and with the parents' permission, Moira scrolled through Emma's recent activity. Social media posts showed nothing unusual – the typical teenage mixture of complaints about school, excitement about weekend plans, and artistic photos of the surrounding countryside. But as Moira dug deeper into Emma's messaging history, she found something that made her pulse quicken.

Three weeks ago, Emma had received a private message from someone calling themselves "ArtMentor47." The initial contact had been a compliment on one of Emma's posted drawings, followed by an offer to provide more personalized feedback on her work. The conversation had continued over several days, with this mentor offering increasingly specific advice about technique and composition. More troubling, the messages gradually shifted toward personal topics – Emma's frustrations with school, her dreams of leaving the Highlands for art school, her feelings of being misunderstood by her peers.

"Mr. and Mrs. MacLeod," Moira called, her voice carefully controlled. "Could you come up here for a moment?"

When the parents appeared in the doorway, Moira showed them the message thread. Janet's face went pale as she read the increasingly intimate conversations between her daughter and the mysterious mentor. The messages painted a picture of careful grooming – someone who had identified Emma's vulnerabilities and exploited them with practiced skill.

"The last message is from the day before she disappeared," Moira explained. "This ArtMentor person suggested they meet in person to discuss Emma's portfolio. Said they were visiting the area and could offer her some real guidance about pursuing art professionally."

David MacLeod's hands clenched into fists. "Why didn't she tell us? We would have... we could have..."

"Predators are skilled at making young people feel like they need to keep secrets," Moira said gently. "They create a sense of special connection, make their victims feel chosen and understood in ways that others supposedly aren't. Emma's artistic talent made her particularly vulnerable to someone who positioned themselves as a mentor and guide."

Moira spent another hour with the MacLeods, gathering details about Emma's movements in the days leading up to her disappearance and compiling a list of her friends and teachers. As she prepared to leave, Janet MacLeod grasped her arm with desperate fingers.

"You'll find her, won't you? You'll bring our Emma home?"

Moira looked into the woman's eyes, seeing the terrible hope that still flickered there despite three days of mounting dread. She had learned over the years not to make promises she couldn't keep, but she also understood that sometimes families needed something to hold onto during the darkest hours.

"I'll do everything in my power," she said simply. "I won't stop looking until we have answers."

Driving back toward Inverness, Moira's mind raced with connections and possibilities. The online grooming of Emma MacLeod provided the first concrete lead in what had seemed like an impossible case, but it also raised disturbing questions about the other missing teenagers. Had they too been contacted by mysterious mentors or new friends who understood them in ways their families couldn't? The pattern of isolation and special attention was textbook predator behavior, but scaled up across multiple victims and a wide geographical area.

Her phone rang as she navigated the winding road that hugged the loch's shoreline. The caller ID showed it was Detective Constable Fraser MacBride, one of the few officers under her command who shared her instinct for seeing connections others missed.

"Fraser, what have you got for me?"

"Been digging into those other missing kids like you asked," his voice crackled through the car's speakers. "Found something interesting. All four of them were active on social media, posting artwork, photography, creative writing – that sort of thing. And here's the kicker – they all received private messages from accounts that claimed to be mentors or talent scouts in the weeks before they disappeared."

Moira felt a surge of vindication mixed with growing alarm. "Different accounts?"

"Aye, but similar patterns. ArtMentor47, TalentScout_Highland, CreativeGuide23 – you get the idea. I've put in requests to the social media companies for account information, but you know how that goes. Could be weeks before we get anything useful, if we get anything at all."

"Keep pushing on those requests. And Fraser? Start looking at any adults in the area who've positioned themselves as art teachers, mentors, or talent scouts. Check community centers, art groups, even informal networks. Someone with access to young artists and the technical knowledge to create multiple online identities."

Moira ended the call and pulled into a layby overlooking the loch. The morning mist had burned off, revealing the dark water in all its brooding majesty. Somewhere out there, four young people had vanished, lured away by someone who understood exactly how to exploit their dreams and vulnerabilities. The methodical nature of the crimes suggested someone with experience, someone who had refined their techniques over time and geography.

She thought again about her encounter with Peggy Thorne at the boat launch. The woman's interest in painting young faces, her isolated cottage, her careful questions about neighbors – it could all be coincidence, but Moira's instincts were screaming otherwise. She pulled out her phone and dialed the station.

"I need a background check run on a Peggy Thorne," she told the duty officer. "Just moved to the Ben Wyvis area. I want to know everything – previous addresses, employment history, any criminal record. And see if there's any record of her actually purchasing property up there."

As she waited for the information, Moira stared out at the loch and tried to piece together a timeline. If the same person was responsible for all four disappearances, they had been operating in the Highlands for at least eight months. But predators didn't simply appear fully formed – they developed their methods over time, often leaving a trail of smaller incidents before escalating to more serious crimes. There might be other missing persons cases from neighboring regions, or reports of suspicious approaches to young artists that hadn't resulted in disappearances.

The phone buzzed with a text message from the duty officer: "No record of property purchase under that name in the Ben Wyvis area. Still checking other databases."

Moira's pulse quickened. Someone was operating under a false identity in an isolated location, claiming to be an artist with an interest in young subjects, and there was no official record of their presence in the area. It might not be enough to convince Chief Inspector Hartwell, but it was enough to justify a closer look.

She started the car and turned toward the winding mountain road that led to Ben Wyvis. If Peggy Thorne was indeed living in an isolated cottage up there, Moira intended to have a conversation with her that went beyond casual pleasantries about landscape painting. Four families were living in agony, waiting for news of their missing children, and every lead – no matter how tenuous – deserved to be pursued with relentless determination.

The Highland landscape grew wilder as she climbed, the road narrowing to a single track with occasional passing places. Ancient stone walls marked long-abandoned croft boundaries, and sheep grazed on hillsides that had known human habitation for thousands of years. It was beautiful country, but also unforgiving – a place where someone could easily disappear without a trace, whether by accident or design.**Chapter 2**

The cottage crouched against the hillside like a stone animal seeking shelter from the Highland wind. Moira parked her patrol car at the end of the rutted track, noting how the building's windows reflected the grey sky in a way that made it impossible to see inside. Smoke rose from the chimney in a thin, steady stream, and several canvases leaned against the exterior wall, though they were turned inward so their subjects remained hidden. The isolation was complete – no neighboring houses were visible, no power lines crossed the landscape, and the only sounds were the whisper of wind through heather and the distant cry of a hawk circling overhead.

As Moira approached the front door, she noticed details that hadn't been visible from the road. Heavy curtains blocked most of the windows, and what appeared to be additional locks had been fitted to the door – unusual for such a remote location where crime was virtually nonexistent. The garden, if it could be called that, was overgrown and wild, but not in the natural way of Highland vegetation. Instead, it had the deliberate untended look of someone who wanted their residence to appear abandoned or uninhabited from a distance.

Before she could knock, the door opened to reveal Peggy Thorne. The woman's pale eyes showed no surprise at finding a police officer on her doorstep, which struck Moira as odd. Most innocent people would display some concern or curiosity when visited by law enforcement, particularly in such an isolated location.

"Sergeant Gash," Peggy said with that same carefully modulated voice Moira remembered from their morning encounter. "I wondered when you might find your way up here. Please, come in. I was just making tea."

The cottage's interior was dim and cluttered, with heavy furniture that seemed too large for the small rooms. But it was the walls that immediately commanded Moira's attention. They were covered with paintings and sketches, dozens of them, all depicting young faces with an almost photographic level of detail. The subjects appeared to range in age from perhaps fourteen to twenty, and while the technical skill was undeniable, there was something deeply unsettling about the collection. The eyes in every portrait seemed to follow the viewer, and many of the expressions captured a mixture of hope and fear that made Moira's skin crawl.

"You're very talented," Moira said carefully, accepting the offered cup of tea while continuing to study the artwork. Several of the faces looked familiar, though she couldn't immediately place where she might have seen them. The paintings showed young people in various settings – some outdoors against Highland backdrops, others in what appeared to be interior spaces with soft lighting that gave their skin an almost luminous quality.

"I've always been drawn to youth as a subject," Peggy replied, settling into an armchair positioned to give her a clear view of both Moira and the room's single exit. "There's something so pure about young faces, before life has had a chance to corrupt or disappoint them. They still believe in possibilities, you know. They still think the world holds magic and wonder, that their dreams might actually come true."

Moira set down her teacup, the porcelain making a small clink against the saucer that seemed unnaturally loud in the close confines of the cottage. Something about the woman's words, combined with the oppressive atmosphere of the room, was making her feel increasingly uneasy. The paintings seemed to leer down from the walls, their youthful subjects trapped forever in Peggy's interpretation of their features and expressions.

"I'm investigating the disappearance of a local girl," Moira said, her voice taking on the professional tone she used when conducting interviews. "Emma MacLeod, from Drumnadrochit. Sixteen years old, artistic, last seen three days ago. I'm talking to anyone new to the area who might have had contact with local young people."

Peggy's pale eyes remained fixed on Moira's face with an intensity that was becoming uncomfortable. The woman's hands rested calmly in her lap, but Moira noticed that her fingers occasionally twitched, as if she were resisting the urge to reach for something. The cottage felt increasingly claustrophobic, and Moira found herself calculating the distance to the door and wondering if her radio would work properly from this remote location.

"I'm afraid I haven't had much contact with the local community yet," Peggy said with that same measured cadence. "I've been focused on setting up my studio and exploring the landscape for suitable subjects. Though I did hear something about missing young people when I stopped for supplies in Beauly last week. Terrible business, families torn apart like that. I imagine it's quite challenging for the police when someone simply vanishes without a trace."

The comment felt like a test, as if Peggy were probing to see how much Moira knew about the broader pattern of disappearances. Moira's instincts, honed by two decades of police work, were now screaming warnings. Everything about this woman felt wrong – from her convenient appearance at the boat launch that morning to her isolated cottage filled with portraits of young faces. But instincts alone wouldn't be enough to convince a judge to issue a search warrant, and Moira knew she needed to be careful not to tip her hand too early.

"Actually, there have been several disappearances over the past eight months," Moira said, watching carefully for any reaction. "Young people from different communities across the Highlands. All of them artistic in some way, all of them contacted by someone online claiming to be a mentor or guide."

For just a moment, something flickered in Peggy's pale eyes – a flash of what might have been satisfaction or pride. But it was gone so quickly that Moira wondered if she had imagined it. The woman's expression remained calm and sympathetic, her posture unchanged in the oversized armchair.

"How awful for their families," Peggy murmured. "Though I suppose young artists have always been vulnerable to those who would exploit their dreams. There's something so trusting about creative souls, isn't there? They want so desperately to believe that someone sees their potential, that someone values their gifts enough to nurture them."

The words sent a chill down Moira's spine. They could have been simple observation, the kind of comment any reasonable person might make when discussing such crimes. But delivered in Peggy's flat, emotionless tone, they sounded more like the analysis of a predator explaining their methodology. Moira found herself studying the woman's face, looking for any crack in the carefully maintained facade.

"I noticed you mentioned painting portraits of young people when we met this morning," Moira said, gesturing toward the walls. "These are quite remarkable. Are they based on live models, or do you work from photographs?"

Peggy's gaze shifted to the paintings, and for the first time since Moira had entered the cottage, her expression showed genuine emotion. There was something almost tender in the way she looked at the portraits, a possessive fondness that made Moira's stomach turn. Several of the faces did look familiar now that she was studying them more carefully, though she still couldn't place exactly where she might have encountered them.

"I prefer working from life when possible," Peggy said softly. "Photographs can never capture the full essence of a subject, the subtle play of emotion across young features, the way hope and fear can exist simultaneously in a single expression. When I paint from life, I can spend time with my subjects, understand their dreams and fears, capture something true about who they are beneath the surface."

Moira's radio crackled suddenly, the sound sharp and intrusive in the cottage's oppressive atmosphere. "Sergeant Gash, this is Control. We've got some information on that background check you requested."

Peggy's eyes fixed on the radio with unmistakable interest, and Moira saw the woman's hands clench slightly in her lap. The mask of calm civility was beginning to slip, revealing something darker underneath. Moira reached for the radio, her movements casual despite the adrenaline beginning to course through her system.

"Go ahead, Control," she said, never taking her eyes off Peggy's face.

"No record of any property purchase under that name. More interesting, though – we found a Peggy Thorne who was questioned in connection with missing persons cases in Wales three years ago. Nothing concrete enough for charges, but the pattern was similar. Young artists, online contact, then disappearances."

The cottage seemed to shrink around them as the implications of the radio message sank in. Peggy's carefully maintained facade cracked entirely, revealing the cold calculation that had been lurking beneath the surface. Her pale eyes now held an unmistakable malevolence, and when she smiled, it was the expression of someone who no longer needed to pretend.

"I suppose this makes things rather awkward," Peggy said, her voice losing its measured cadence and taking on a more natural tone that was somehow far more threatening. "I had hoped to have more time to complete my current project before circumstances forced me to relocate again. But I've learned to adapt to changing situations over the years."

Moira's hand moved instinctively toward her radio, but Peggy was already rising from her chair with a fluid motion that suggested she had been preparing for this possibility. The woman moved with surprising speed for someone of her apparent age, and Moira realized that she had seriously underestimated the danger she was in. The cottage's isolation, which had seemed like an advantage for conducting a discreet investigation, now felt like a potentially fatal trap.

"Where are they?" Moira demanded, her voice steady despite the fear beginning to claw at her chest. "Where are Emma and the others?"

Peggy's smile widened, revealing teeth that seemed too sharp in the cottage's dim lighting. She moved toward one of the heavily curtained windows, her hand resting on what Moira now realized was a wooden club that had been leaning against the wall, disguised among what appeared to be painting supplies. The woman's movements were confident and practiced, suggesting she had been through similar confrontations before.

"Such a direct question, Sergeant. But I think you'll find that the answers aren't as simple as you might hope. Art, you see, requires sacrifice. True beauty demands that something be given up, something precious and irreplaceable. My young subjects understand this eventually, though it sometimes takes time for them to fully appreciate the honor I'm offering them."

Moira's mind raced as she tried to process the implications of Peggy's words while simultaneously calculating her options for escape or confrontation. The cottage had only one visible exit, and Peggy was now positioned between Moira and the door. The windows were heavily curtained and might be difficult to break through quickly, and even if she managed to escape the building, she was miles from the nearest help across treacherous Highland terrain.

But four young people were missing, and Emma MacLeod's family was waiting for answers that only this woman could provide. Moira had spent her career facing dangerous situations, and her training kicked in despite the fear and adrenaline flooding her system. She shifted her weight slightly, preparing to move, while keeping her voice calm and professional.

"I need you to tell me where they are, Peggy. Their families deserve to know what happened to them. Whatever you've done, whatever you think you're accomplishing, those young people have families who love them and need closure."

The woman's laugh was like glass breaking, sharp and dangerous in the cottage's close atmosphere. She lifted the wooden club, testing its weight in her hands while studying Moira with the cold assessment of a predator evaluating prey. The paintings on the walls seemed to watch the confrontation with their trapped, youthful eyes, silent witnesses to whatever horrors had been committed in this isolated place.

"Families," Peggy repeated, her voice dripping with contempt. "Small minds who could never understand what their children were capable of becoming. Do you think Emma's parents truly appreciated her gift? Could they see the potential that burned in her young soul, the way she could capture the essence of Highland light in a few simple pencil strokes? They would have let her settle for ordinary life, marriage to some local fisherman, children who would trap her in domesticity until her talent withered and died."

The woman's obsession was becoming clearer, and Moira felt a sick understanding of what had driven the disappearances. This wasn't random predation but something more twisted – a deluded belief that she was somehow preserving or honoring the artistic talents of young people by removing them from their families and communities. The portraits on the walls took on a more sinister meaning as Moira wondered if they represented the only remains of the missing teenagers.**Chapter 3**

The silence stretched between them like a taut wire, broken only by the whisper of Highland wind against the cottage's stone walls and the soft ticking of an antique clock somewhere in the shadows. Moira's eyes never left Peggy's face as she slowly reached for her radio, her movements deliberate and unthreatening. The woman's grip on the wooden club tightened, but she made no move to stop Moira from keying the transmission button. Perhaps she believed herself beyond capture now, or maybe years of successfully evading law enforcement had made her overconfident in her ability to handle unexpected complications.

"Control, this is Sergeant Gash," Moira said quietly into the radio. "I need immediate backup at the Ben Wyvis cottage location. Suspect in custody for questioning regarding the missing persons cases. And Control? Send the tactical team and contact Detective Inspector Morrison. We're going to need a full forensic sweep of this location."

Peggy's pale eyes glittered with something that might have been amusement. She set the club down against her chair but remained standing, her posture alert and ready. The cottage felt like a stage set waiting for the final act of a long-running play, with its oppressive atmosphere and walls lined with the faces of young victims. Moira found herself wondering how many other locations like this existed, hidden away in remote corners of Britain where a predator could operate without fear of discovery for months or even years at a time.

"You're assuming, of course, that your colleagues will arrive in time to be of any use," Peggy said conversationally. "This is quite isolated country, Sergeant Gash. Accidents happen to people who venture into the Highlands alone, particularly when the weather turns harsh or the terrain proves treacherous. A dedicated police officer, pushing herself too hard in pursuit of a case that was consuming her thoughts, might easily lose her footing on a steep slope or become disoriented in the mist that rolls in so suddenly from the lochs."

The woman's words carried the weight of experience, suggesting she had considered various scenarios for disposing of unwanted visitors to her remote sanctuary. Moira felt her training take over completely now, the fear and revulsion giving way to the cold focus that had served her well in dangerous situations throughout her career. She began to mentally catalog everything she could see in the cottage that might serve as evidence or provide clues to the fate of the missing teenagers. The paintings were obviously significant, but there might be other items hidden among the cluttered furniture and art supplies that could reveal the full scope of Peggy's crimes.

"The families deserve to know what happened to their children," Moira said, her voice steady despite the adrenaline coursing through her system. "Emma MacLeod's parents are dying inside, wondering if their daughter is hurt or afraid or calling out for them. The same is true for the other families. Whatever you've done, however you justify it to yourself, you're torturing innocent people who love those kids more than their own lives."

Peggy moved toward one of the heavily curtained windows, pulling the fabric aside just enough to peer out at the Highland landscape beyond. The late afternoon light filtered through the gap, casting strange shadows across the portraits that lined the walls. Moira could hear the distant sound of helicopter rotors now, growing steadily louder as they approached across the mountainous terrain. The tactical team would be here soon, but the woman seemed unconcerned by the approaching law enforcement presence.

"Love," Peggy repeated, her voice taking on a mocking tone. "Such a limiting emotion, don't you think? These parents claimed to love their children, but their love was possessive and small-minded. They wanted to keep their young artists close, to mold them into conventional lives that would waste their extraordinary gifts. I offered them something far more precious – the chance to become eternal, to have their beauty and talent preserved forever at the peak of their potential."

The implications of her words hit Moira like a physical blow. The past tense references to the missing teenagers, combined with the woman's talk of preservation and eternal beauty, suggested that Emma and the others might already be beyond rescue. The portraits on the walls might indeed be the only remaining traces of four young lives that had been snuffed out in service of this madwoman's twisted artistic vision. Moira forced herself to remain professional and focused, though every instinct screamed at her to demand immediate answers about the teenagers' whereabouts.

"Where are their bodies, Peggy?" Moira asked quietly. "These families need to lay their children to rest with dignity. They need to grieve properly and find some measure of peace. You can still do one decent thing here – tell me where you put them so their parents can bring them home."

The woman turned from the window with a expression of genuine surprise, as if she couldn't understand why anyone would be concerned with such mundane matters as burial and mourning rituals. Her pale eyes held the flat emptiness that Moira had learned to associate with true psychopaths – individuals who could commit the most heinous acts without experiencing normal human emotions like guilt or remorse. The helicopter sounds were much closer now, and Moira could hear the rumble of vehicles navigating the rough track that led to the cottage.

"Bodies," Peggy said thoughtfully, as if considering the word for the first time. "Such a crude way to think about what remains when the soul has been properly captured and preserved. I suppose you'll want to poke through the landscape with your shovels and your metal detectors, disturbing the peace of this beautiful place in search of conventional evidence. But you're thinking too literally, Sergeant Gash. My art isn't about death – it's about transcendence."

The cottage door suddenly exploded inward as tactical officers in full gear flooded into the small space, their weapons trained on Peggy while barked commands filled the air. Moira identified herself and backed away to give the team room to work, though her eyes never left the woman's face. Even surrounded by armed police, Peggy Thorne showed no fear or distress. If anything, she seemed pleased by the dramatic escalation, as if the arrival of law enforcement added an exciting element to whatever game she had been playing with their solitary lives.

"Peggy Thorne, you're under arrest on suspicion of kidnapping and murder," the team leader announced as officers moved to secure the suspect. "You have the right to remain silent, but anything you do say may be given in evidence against you in court."

As the woman was cuffed and read her rights, Moira found herself studying the portraits with new urgency. Four missing teenagers, four families waiting for answers, and a cottage full of painted faces that might represent the only clues to their fate. The forensic team would need to photograph every piece of artwork, analyze every surface for DNA evidence, and conduct a thorough search of the surrounding landscape. Sergeant Moira Gash pulled her oars through the dark water with practiced strokes, her breath forming small clouds in the crisp air. This was her sanctuary, these pre-dawn hours when Inverness still slumbered and the world belonged only to her and the ancient waters that had shaped her since childhood.

She had been rowing these lochs for thirty-seven years, first as a gangly child desperate to escape the cramped tenement where her mother's coughing fits echoed through paper-thin walls, then as a teenager seeking solace from the relentless teasing about her unusual height and angular features. Now, at forty-two, with silver threading through her auburn hair and lines etched around her green eyes from years of squinting into Scottish weather, rowing remained her constant companion. The rhythmic pull of the oars, the burn in her shoulders, the way the boat glided forward with each stroke – these sensations grounded her in ways that her work as a police sergeant rarely could.

The radio crackled to life on the seat beside her, shattering the morning's peace. "Control to Sergeant Gash. Priority call. Missing person report just came in. Teenage girl, last seen three days ago in Drumnadrochit."

Moira shipped her oars and reached for the radio, water dripping from her gloved fingers onto the plastic casing. "Gash here. Details?"

"Sixteen-year-old Emma MacLeod. Parents say she was walking to meet friends at the village hall but never arrived. Her mobile's going straight to voicemail. Family's beside themselves."

Another missing teenager. That made four in the past eight months across the Highlands – all between fifteen and eighteen, all seemingly vanishing without a trace. The official line was that young people sometimes ran away, seeking adventure in Glasgow or Edinburgh, but something in Moira's gut suggested otherwise. In her twenty years of police work, she had developed an instinct for patterns that others missed, connections that existed in shadows and silences rather than in official reports.

"I'll be there in forty minutes," she said into the radio. "Have someone canvas the route from her house to the village hall again. And get me everything we have on the other missing kids from the past year."

"Already on it, Sarge. Though the brass won't like you connecting cases without evidence."

Moira allowed herself a bitter smile. Chief Inspector Hartwell had made his feelings clear about her "tendency toward conspiracy theories" during their last heated exchange. He was a numbers man, focused on clearance rates and budget constraints, not on the subtle wrongness that seemed to permeate these disappearances. But Moira had learned to trust her instincts, even when they led her into conflict with superiors who preferred neat explanations to messy truths.

She started the small outboard motor and turned toward shore, the peaceful morning now shadowed by thoughts of another family's nightmare. The boat cut through the mist-shrouded water as she mentally reviewed what she knew about the missing teenagers. They came from different towns scattered across the Highlands, with no apparent connection to each other. Different schools, different social circles, different backgrounds. Yet something linked them, something that existed beyond the reach of conventional investigation.

As she approached the boat launch, Moira noticed an unfamiliar figure standing on the small wooden dock. A woman, perhaps in her fifties, wearing a paint-stained smock over dark clothing. Her grey hair was pulled back severely, and her pale blue eyes seemed to track Moira's approach with unusual intensity. Most people avoided the launch this early in the morning, preferring the warmth of their beds to the Highland chill.

"Beautiful morning for rowing," the woman called out as Moira guided her boat alongside the dock. Her voice carried a slight accent that Moira couldn't immediately place – perhaps Welsh, or from somewhere in the south of England.

"Aye, it is that," Moira replied, securing her boat and beginning to lift it from the water. Despite her lean build, years of rowing had given her considerable upper body strength, and she could manage the lightweight craft on her own.

"I'm Peggy," the woman said, stepping closer. "Peggy Thorne. I've just moved to the area – bought the old cottage up on Ben Wyvis. Thought I might try my hand at some landscape painting while the light is still soft."

Moira paused in securing her boat. Something about the woman's manner struck her as off – too casual, too carefully rehearsed. And there was something else, a quality to her pale eyes that made Moira's policeman instincts prickle with unease.

"Remote spot for painting," Moira observed. "Not many neighbors up that way."

"Oh, I prefer solitude for my work," Peggy said with a smile that didn't quite reach her eyes. "I do portraits, mostly. Young people have such interesting faces, don't you think? So full of possibility and hope. I find them endlessly fascinating subjects."

The radio crackled again, reminding Moira of the missing girl and her waiting duties. She lifted her equipment bag and nodded politely to the strange woman. "Well, I hope you find what you're looking for up here."

Perhaps it was the woman's intense focus on young faces, or the way she had seemed to be waiting specifically for someone to arrive at the boat launch. The MacLeod house sat on a hill overlooking Loch Ness, its windows facing the dark water that had made their village famous.
